sentence.text: Patient 2 (a girl) was the third child of healthy, unrelated parents.
One sibling had Down syndrome.
Conventional ultrasound at 20 weeks’ gestation revealed a presumptive craniosynostosis.
Amniocentesis was carried out in the Erasmus Medical Centre in Rotterdam.
Initially, no mutations were found in the FGFR genes and the TWIST gene.
However, only hot spots associated with the well-delineated craniosynostosis syndromes were analyzed.
At 28 + 5 weeks’ gestation, the craniosynostosis was confirmed by 3D ultrasound.
The girl was born in breech position at term by primary caesarean section.
Her birth weight was 3,610 g.
The Apgar scores were 8 and 9 after 1 and 5 minutes, respectively.

Physical examination of the newborn revealed a cloverleaf-shaped skull, cutis gyrata on the forehead, ocular hypertelorism and marked proptosis, down-slanted palpebral fissures, prominent umbilical stump, and an anteriorly placed anus ( Fig 2 A ).
She also had a unilateral choanal atresia.
Skin on the arms was abundant, and acanthosis nigricans was lacking.

Respiratory failure gradually developed, and, given the suspected diagnosis of BSS and expected poor prognosis, a multidisciplinary team of pediatricians and surgeons decided not to intubate or resuscitate.
She died after 3 days.

Postmortem cranial MRI revealed a simplified gyral pattern (gyral index 1.5; Fig 2 B), abnormal anatomy of the hippocampus on coronal MRI ( Fig 2 C), and obstructive hydrocephaly, but no tonsillar herniation ( Fig 2 D).
The pons/brainstem was compressed at the level of the clivus ( Fig 2 D), which was possibly the cause of her respiratory failure and death.
Postmortem MRI of the thorax revealed a butterfly shape of the seventh thoracic vertebra.
Abdominal MRI was normal.
Postnatally, a de novo Tyr375Cys mutation was found in the FGFR2 gene.
